result.execSummary:
The defendant Sarah M Mataya was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Escape while under Extended Supervision, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.42(2m).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Cost and Surcharge to be paid at the rate of $50.00 per month starting 04-15-2015 and/or 52 hours of Community Service to be completed by March 15, 2016.  Court must receive notice of completion prior to 03-15-2016.  Failure to pay or complete Community Service the Court order 10 days Huber as Contempt for non-compliance with Court Order.

First 60 days Straight Time.  Remaining Huber with standard release conditions.

Last 100 Days STAYED for 60 days of Day Report Center.  If the defendant successfully completes Day Report Center the Court Orders the Last 100 Days PERMANENTLY  STAYED.
Concurrent with: Case #13CF941.
Defendant to Provide DNA Sample, if not yet provided.  Pay Surcharge.

Defendant Sarah M Mataya in court, in custody, with attorney Mark E. Kershek.   Lesli S. Boese appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Plea Colloquy.

Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count 1.  Court finds defendant guilty.

The Court Orders the Following:

Imposed  Sentence of:

120 Days Jail (First 60 days Straight time remaining Huber WITH STANDARD RELEASE CONDITIONS).  CONCURRENT TO 13CF941
Last 100 days Stayed for 60 days of DRC.  If the defendant successfully completes day report center the court orders the last 100 days  permanently stayed.

Failure to pay or complete community service the Court orders  10 days Huber as contempt for non-compliance with Court Order).
